articles.headline: Citigroup Plans to Split Itself Up, Taking Apart the Financial Supermarket
articles.snippet: Citigroup is moving to dismantle large parts of its troubled financial empire, undoing the landmark merger that created the company a decade ago.
articles.abstract: Citigroup is moving to dismantle large parts of its troubled financial empire, undoing the landmark merger that created the company a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Staggered by losses despite two federal rescues, Citigroup is accelerating moves to dismantle parts of its troubled financial empire in an effort to placate regulators and its anxious investors.

articles.headline: Former Chief of Autodesk Takes Reins at Yahoo
articles.snippet: Yahoo said that it had named Carol Bartz, the chairwoman and former chief executive of the software maker Autodesk, as its new leader, succeeding its co-founder Jerry Yang.
articles.abstract: Yahoo said that it had named Carol Bartz, the chairwoman and former chief executive of the software maker Autodesk, as its new leader, succeeding its co-founder Jerry Yang.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In tapping Carol Bartz as Yahoo’s new chief executive on Tuesday, the company’s board has selected a seasoned manager and tough-minded technology executive who established Autodesk, the maker of design software, as a market leader and successfully steered it through a boom and bust cycle.

articles.headline: Afghan Girls, Scarred by Acid, Defy Terror, Embracing School
articles.snippet: Despite threats and an acid attack on several students two months ago, the Mirwais School for Girls is thriving.
articles.abstract: Despite threats and an acid attack on several students two months ago, the Mirwais School for Girls is thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — One morning two months ago, Shamsia Husseini and her sister were walking through the muddy streets to the local girls school when a man pulled alongside them on a motorcycle and posed what seemed like an ordinary question.

articles.headline: A Device to Avert Strokes Lacks Proof That It Works
articles.snippet: A device intended to prevent strokes provides a case study of how the actions of many can combine to undercut the gathering of reliable medical evidence.
articles.abstract: A device intended to prevent strokes provides a case study of how the actions of many can combine to undercut the gathering of reliable medical evidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every year, experts estimate, about 80,000 seemingly healthy people in this country under the age of 55 have a stroke for no apparent reason. Some researchers have long suspected that one culprit is a cardiac defect that 40 percent of those people share — a tiny congenital opening between the upper chambers of their hearts.

articles.headline: In Michigan, Bank Lends Little of Its Bailout Funds
articles.snippet: A look at one bank’s handling of its bailout money highlights the challenges that U.S. banks are confronting.
articles.abstract: A look at one bank’s handling of its bailout money highlights the challenges that U.S. banks are confronting.
articles.lead_paragraph: TROY, Mich. — The bad bets made by executives at Independent Bank of Michigan are on display in spots across the state: a defunct bowling alley, a new but never occupied shopping center and the luxurious Whispering Woods Estates, which offers prime lots for never-constructed dream homes.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Love the Long Eyelashes. Who’s Your Doctor?
articles.snippet: The company behind Botox plans to introduce the first F.D.A.-approved drug for growing longer eyelashes.
articles.abstract: The company behind Botox plans to introduce the first F.D.A.-approved drug for growing longer eyelashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: First it was frozen foreheads. Now it’s Betty Boop eyelashes.

articles.headline: Banks in Need of Even More Bailout Money
articles.snippet: Even some of the bailout program’s harshest critics acknowledge that things most likely would be even worse without it.
articles.abstract: Even some of the bailout program’s harshest critics acknowledge that things most likely would be even worse without it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even before word came on Tuesday that Citigroup might split into pieces to shore up its finances, an unpleasant message was moving through Congress and President-elect Barack Obama’s transition team: the banks need more taxpayer money.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Geithner Questioned on Tax Returns
articles.snippet: Timothy F. Geithner, the president-elect’s choice for Treasury secretary, failed to pay more than $34,000 in taxes early this decade.
articles.abstract: Timothy F. Geithner, the president-elect’s choice for Treasury secretary, failed to pay more than $34,000 in taxes early this decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Timothy F. Geithner, President-elect Barack Obama’s choice for Treasury secretary, failed to pay more than $34,000 in federal taxes over several years early this decade, and also faces questions about the employment papers of a former household employee, suddenly complicating what had seemed to be an easy confirmation process in the Senate.

articles.headline: Some States in a Pinch May Raise Gasoline Tax
articles.snippet: Several states are considering the rare step of raising gasoline taxes to help fill growing budget gaps and potholed roads.
articles.abstract: Several states are considering the rare step of raising gasoline taxes to help fill growing budget gaps and potholed roads.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several states are considering the rare step of raising gasoline taxes to help fill growing budget gaps and potholed roads.

articles.headline: Clinton Pledges Tough Diplomacy and a Fast Start
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton parried doubts about her husband’s fund-raising and emerged from a hearing headed for swift approval as secretary of state.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton parried doubts about her husband’s fund-raising and emerged from a hearing headed for swift approval as secretary of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday deflected calls for greater limits on her husband’s fund-raising, struck a sharper tone toward Israel on violence in the Middle East and emerged from a daylong confirmation hearing headed for swift approval as secretary of state.
